awd_titl_txt: Magnetospheric Resonances at Middle and Low Latitudes
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant supports an investigation into the dynamics behind the coupling of Earth's ionosphere and magnetosphere. It is important to understand how Earth's magnetic field couples to the outer layers of the atmosphere as a background to understanding how space weather effects the very near-Earth environment and ultimately societies most critical space and ground based assets. This study supports education and training in the fields of data analysis, numerical simulations and space plasma physics for one PhD student. In addition, it includes collaboration between national labs (Air Force Research Laboratory and U.S. Naval Research Laboratory) and an academic institution (Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University). The results of this study will be disseminated through public outreach events including lectures at local high schools.

This project will specifically examine the relative importance of the field line resonator and the ionospheric Alfven resonator in generating Ultra Low Frequency waves at middle and low latitudes. This will be achieved through use of reduced two-fluid magnetohydrodynamics model in 2D and 3D which includes ionospheric conductance and collisions. SAMI is Another Model of the Ionosphere 3 (SAMI3) model data and Communication/Navigation Outage Forecasting System (C/NOFS) satellite data will provide ionospheric input to the model. The outcomes will be compared with magnetic observations conducted at South American Meridional B-Field Array (SAMBA) stations in Antarctica and Chile.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Ultra-low frequency (ULF) electromagnetic waves play a crucial role in the coupling between the Earth's ionosphere and magnetosphere.  They actively participate in every aspects of the exchange of mass, momentum, and energy between the ionosphere and magnetosphere.

Observations performed on the ground station and multiple satellites demonstrate that intense small-scale ULF waves and currents are also observed in the subauroral zone. Specifically, they are frequently detected at middle altitudes corresponding to the location of the plasmapause, which is the boundary between the dense and cold plasma co-rotating with the Earth and the hot and diluted plasma in the Earth’s magnetotail.

This region is populated with very energetic protons which can efficiently interact with the ULF waves via cyclotron wave-particle resonances.  And the various aspects of the wave-particle interaction attracts significant attention nowadays because protons with energies more than 30 MeV have already become a problem for commercial and military satellites on low-Earth orbits. It is expected that they will cause more damage to the next generations of satellites with smaller and higher-integrated electronics onboard, particularly in the region of South Atlantic Anomaly.

Also ULF waves  waves and associated FACs produces small scale, intence density disturbances in the ionosphere which can cause significant problems for the GPS recievers and any other applications involving propagation of radiowaves through the ionosphere.

One of the main questions related to the origin and dynamics of large-amplitude ULF waves and FACs is what is the physical mechanism responsible for the generation of these waves inside the resonator? The results from our studies provide a definitive answer to this question: These waves  are produced by the so-called Ionospheric Feedback Instability (IFI), driven by the large-scale electric field in the ionosphere.

During the time of this NSF award, we performed a comprehensive numerical and theoreticval study of structure and dynamics of ULF waves detected in the low and middle latitude magnetospehere. We did numerical simulations of the two-fluid MHD model and compared the numerical results with data measured on the ground and on multiple satellites in the subauroral zone.

The main results from our reseach are published in one PhD Dissertaion, 8 peer-reviewed papers, and 15 talks/posters at scientific meetings and conferences. These results are:

  1. We analyzed ULF magnetic fluctuations detected  by the ACE satellite in the solar wind in the L1 Lagrangian point and observed with the ground magnetometers at high (𝐿 = 5.76), middle (𝐿 = 2.46), and low (𝐿 = 1.87) latitudes during 84 intense substorms. Our analysis reveals that there is a good correlation between oscillations with frequencies less than 1 mHz in the solar wind and in three different latitudes during strong substorms. Therefore, there is a strong coupling between the Earth’s magnetosphere–ionosphere system and the solar wind in the frequency range below 1 mHz mediated by the disturbances in the magnetic field.
  2. We performed a numerical study of the ULF waves detected by the ground magnetometers at middle latitudes during substorm. We showed that these waves are generated by the ionospheric feedback instability driven by the large-scale electric field associated with the surface waves propagating along the ambient magnetic field on a strong perpendicular gradient in the plasma density occurring in the equatorial magnetosphere. The gradient in the plasma density is associated with the plasmapause. 
  3. We demonstrated that the plasmapause is indeed a special location in the magnetosphere, where the small-scale ULF electromagnetic waves and the large-scale quasi-stationary electric fields must be observed during substorms. It works as a power plant in the magnetosphere: It converts the kinetic energy of the hot particles moving toward the Earth from the magnetotail during a substorm into the energy of the large-scale, quasi-stationary electric field (Figure 1).
  4. We used this concept to explain small-scale, electromagnetic ULF waves and large-scale quasi-stationary electric field observed in the vicinity of the plasmapause by the CRRES, DMSP, and RBSP satellites. The observations have been reproduced with numerical results from two-fluid MHD simulations (Figure 2 and 3).
  5. We developed a novel scenario of the formation of luminous structures at midlatitude ionospohere within strong subauroral ion drifts (SAID) regions. These structures are called  STEVE and Picket Fence (Figure 4).
  6. We revealed the inner electromagnetic structure of STEVE-associated fast SAID and performed its numerical investigation based on the ionospheric feedback mechanism. A good, quantitative agreement between the observed and simulated results indicates that the model captures the basic underlying physics of the nonlinear magnetosphere-ionosphere coupling in the STEVE/SAID region.
